oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Doug Stone Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Doug Stone (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Doug Stone; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Doug Stone describes a song [unidentified], that was written for him, that he relates to -- (00:15) Stone reveals that a song [unidentified] caused a member of CBS to get on their hands and knees -- (00:47) Stone recalls working in Kentucky, and Biff Collie and Stone discuss how Stone enjoys nature -- (01:32) Collie has Stone reflect on his studio career; Stone discusses his live performance career while in a 'dance band' -- (02:50) "Turn This Thing Around" is described by Stone as a play on words about someone who decided not to leave their partner -- (03:33) Collie introduces Stone and "Crying on Your Shoulder Again;" Stone describes how his initial impression of "Crying on Your Shoulder Again" was wrong -- (04:10) Stone reveals how he grew up in Newnan, Georgia; additionally, Stone describes his relationship with Alan Jackson and how they share the same hometown -- (05:33) Collie and Stone discuss "These Lips Don't Know How to Say Goodbye," and Stone recalls the amount of practice he had done for "These Lips Don't Know How to Say Goodbye" -- (06:38) Collie has Stone address his self-image as a song-writer -- (07:19) Collie reveals his collection of articles praising Stone, and Stone reflects on the expectations of success -- (08:55) Stone describes how he met his producer (Doug Johnson) -- (09:22) Stone reflects on the first contract he had signed, and Stone describes how he went to Johnson for some records -- (10:34) Stone recalls how Johnson got Stone a tryout with CBS Records -- (11:43) "We Always Agree on Love" is described as a song about people who only agree on their love for each other -- (12:06) Collie has Stone list his favorite people; Stone chooses to discuss Hercules -- (13:13) Stone says that the drums are his best instrument -- (13:51) Stone relates "My Hat's Off to Him" to his lucky number (3) -- (14:55) Collie has Stone reflect on his belief in lucky numbers -- (16:12) "It's a Good Thing I Don't Love You Anymore" is addressed by Stone for its word play -- (16:43) Collie and Stone discuss how Stone's mother had an effect on Stone's musical career -- (17:23) "High Weeds and Rust" is said to be about a man abandoned by his wife by Stone -- (18:03) Collie recaps Stone's background, and Stone revealed how he performed with Loretta Lynn when he was seven -- (19:26) Collie has Stone reflect on his disc jockey career -- (19:49) Stone performs goodbye radio spot -- (20:01) Stone says goodbye
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Stone, Doug, 1956-; Collie, Biff;
